headline.main: PARTS OF CHALLENGER CABIN RETRIEVED AS WEATHER EASES

results.snippet: Navy salvage divers today hauled up more silt-covered wreckage from the space shuttle Challenger's crew cabin and planned to return to port Tuesday night to unload debris and take on fresh supplies.   The U.S.S. Preserver, anchored 16 miles...
results.lead_paragraph: Navy salvage divers today hauled up more silt-covered wreckage from the space shuttle Challenger's crew cabin and planned to return to port Tuesday night to unload debris and take on fresh supplies. The U.S.S. Preserver, anchored 16 miles offshore over the crash site of Challenger's smashed crew compartment, told salvage control on shore that bottom visibility had improved and divers were making progress recovering debris after a long bout with high winds and choppy seas. ''My intentions are to return to port tomorrow evening after the dive day, primarily for a logistics run,'' the ship radioed.

headline.main: PART OF SPACE SHUTTLE'S BOOSTER JOINT FOUND IN SEA

results.snippet: Space agency engineers said today that a piece of the Challenger wreckage found two weeks ago included part of the joint of the right solid-fuel booster rocket, the main suspect in the accident investigation.   Rocket engineers from the Marshall...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Space agency engineers said today that a piece of the Challenger wreckage found two weeks ago included part of the joint of the right solid-fuel booster rocket, the main suspect in the accident investigation. Rocket engineers from the Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala., were examining the salvaged fragment, a twisted piece of metal about 10 feet by 15 feet, for clues to any malfunction of the joint that might have caused the space shuttle to explode Jan. 28, killing the crew of seven. They also were studying the part for insights into how to redesign the boosters for future shuttle flights. This was the first confirmation that the Navy salvage team had recovered a key part of the right booster rocket. But the portion of the joint that apparently failed and led to the explosion was missing from the recovered wreckage.

headline.main: INTERVIEWS DISCLOSE OLD, SOMETIMES BITTER RESENTMENTS IN ASTRONAUT CORPS

results.snippet: Longstanding strains and resentments in the astronaut corps have come to the surface in the aftermath of the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger on Jan. 28, according to interviews with current and former astronauts.   The new head of the...

byline.original: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Longstanding strains and resentments in the astronaut corps have come to the surface in the aftermath of the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger on Jan. 28, according to interviews with current and former astronauts. The new head of the shuttle program, Rear Adm. Richard H. Truly of the Navy, after meeting privately with the astronaut corps last week, said he expected some of the astronauts to quit the program soon, but not ''in a huff.'' Admiral Truly's remark only hinted at the internal tensions in the 95-member astronaut corps. Old and sometimes bitter strains, said to stem from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's style of management and manner of facing safety problems, have become apparent in the weeks since the loss of five of the astronauts' colleagues and two other crew members in the explosion of the Challenger.

headline.main: THE PANEL'S GOALS

results.snippet: In the first hint of changes they will recommend for the space shuttle program, members of the Presidential commission investigating the Challenger accident said they would urge the creation of a watchdog group with the power to postpone flights...

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: In the first hint of changes they will recommend for the space shuttle program, members of the Presidential commission investigating the Challenger accident said they would urge the creation of a watchdog group with the power to postpone flights for safety reasons. The members also hinted strongly that they would favor a major design change that would enable astronauts to escape in case of imminent disaster. When the Challenger blew up on Jan. 28, all seven astronauts died. Both changes seem likely to meet resistance from some top managers at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, who have said privately in recent weeks that both the shuttle program and their own chain of command can be patched to fly again. And even the astronaut corps seems divided over the need for an escape mechanism, which could greatly extend the delay of shuttle flights.

headline.main: NASA OFFICIAL SAYS SHUTTLE PROGRAM HAD MAJOR FLAWS

results.snippet: A top space agency official testified today that there were major flaws in the management of the space shuttle program in the months leading up to the explosion of the Challenger.   The official, Arnold Aldrich, testified that although he was head...

byline.original: By PHILIP M. BOFFEY, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A top space agency official testified today that there were major flaws in the management of the space shuttle program in the months leading up to the explosion of the Challenger. The official, Arnold Aldrich, testified that although he was head of the entire shuttle program, he was never informed of the issues being raised about the safety of joints in the booster rockets in months of discussions among engineers from the company that built the rockets and from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration itself. A failure in those joints is believed to have caused the Challenger disaster Jan. 28, in which the crew of seven astronauts died. Failure in Communications Mr. Aldrich, who is based at the Johnson Space Center in Houston, said the joints' problems had been discussed at the Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala., and at NASA headquarters in Washington, but the problems were ''not brought through my office in either direction.'' According to the shuttle program's organizational charts, Mr. Aldrich is the manager of the national shuttle program. The Marshall center, which is responsible for the booster rockets, was supposed to report major problems to him.

headline.main: KEY POINTS FROM HEARING ON EXPLOSION OF THE SPACE SHUTTLE

results.snippet: Following are excerpts from a transcript of hearings on the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, held in Washington yesterday by a Presidential investigative panel, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC Radio News:  ...
results.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from a transcript of hearings on the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, held in Washington yesterday by a Presidential investigative panel, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC Radio News: JOHN W. YOUNG: Last year was a incredibly good year for the space program. We flew nine space shuttle missions, which was four more than we flew in '84, and we almost flew 10. But we had hold kills and one remanifest, and people say, well, that's bad luck. Well, I tell you, when you have a hold kill in this vehicle, the best place to have it is before liftoff. There's no doubt about it. We had to do a remanifest and if you're not ready to fly that's exactly what you ought to do. So I think those were good luck. DR. RICHARD P. FEYNMAN: Sir, what's a hold kill and what's a remanifest? YOUNG: A hold kill is when you're down there at the launch pad. You get right up to engine start and the engine doesn't start or it starts and then shuts down because it has a problem. A remanifest is when you roll back and decide to go with another payload. So you put a new payload in. FEYNMAN: Thank you. WILLIAM P. ROGERS: Did at the end of 1985 your office feel that you had had too much to do?

headline.main: NASA May Face Sweeping Change Before It Flies

results.snippet: If a Presidential commission has its way - and there seems reason to believe that it will - the National Aeronautics and Space Administration will have to change some of its software as well as some of its hardware before the shuttle next flies.  ...
results.lead_paragraph: If a Presidential commission has its way - and there seems reason to believe that it will - the National Aeronautics and Space Administration will have to change some of its software as well as some of its hardware before the shuttle next flies. At a hearing last week in Washington, Arnold Aldrich, the head of the shuttle program, said he had not been informed of concern over the booster rocket joints that are believed to have been responsible for the explosion that destroyed the Challenger and killed its crew in January. In an effort to focus more attention on such worries, panel members said they would recommend the creation of a watchdog group with the power to postpone flights for safety reasons.

headline.main: Soviet Admits an Astronaut Was Killed in 1961 Accident

results.snippet: The Soviet Union has admitted, apparently for the first time, that an astronaut was burned to death while training for a flight in the early days of the Soviet space program.   The Government newspaper Izvestia said Wednesday that the astronaut,...
results.lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union has admitted, apparently for the first time, that an astronaut was burned to death while training for a flight in the early days of the Soviet space program. The Government newspaper Izvestia said Wednesday that the astronaut, Valentin Bondarenko, died in March 1961 at the age of 24 after fire swept through his space training capsule.

headline.main: QUESTIONS WITHOUT ANSWERS

results.snippet: Often an event captures headlines, then fades from view with important questions unanswered - questions that defy news reporting, at least for a while. This column periodically offers a selection of such questions.   ''SHALL I DIE? SHALL I FLY?''...
results.lead_paragraph: Often an event captures headlines, then fades from view with important questions unanswered - questions that defy news reporting, at least for a while. This column periodically offers a selection of such questions. ''SHALL I DIE? SHALL I FLY?'' Are these Shakespeare's words? The question was raised in November when an untitled love poem that opened with that line was attributed to Shakespeare. Gary Taylor, an American scholar who lives in England, made the discovery in the well-combed archives of the Bodleian Library in Oxford among 50 poems by Herrick, Donne, Jonson and others. The nine-stanza work included internal rhymes that resembled Shakespeare's, Mr. Taylor said, offering arguments based on similarities to other writings by the Bard.

headline.main: CORRECTION

results.snippet: A Houston dispatch last Thursday on astronauts in the National Aeronautics and Space Administration incorrectly described the career plans of Bruce McCandless 2d, a veteran astronaut. He says he intends to remain with the agency for the foreseeable...
results.lead_paragraph: A Houston dispatch last Thursday on astronauts in the National Aeronautics and Space Administration incorrectly described the career plans of Bruce McCandless 2d, a veteran astronaut. He says he intends to remain with the agency for the foreseeable future.

headline.main: SOVIET CELEBRATES START OF AGE OF SPACE TRAVEL

results.snippet: In this factory town where Yuri A. Gagarin grew up, the 25th anniversary of manned space flight was marked today much as the Fourth of July is marked in small-town America, with bands and footraces, self-conscious pomp and simple pride.   Families,...

byline.original: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: In this factory town where Yuri A. Gagarin grew up, the 25th anniversary of manned space flight was marked today much as the Fourth of July is marked in small-town America, with bands and footraces, self-conscious pomp and simple pride. Families, clustered under umbrellas in a driving snowstorm, passed the Gagarin Museum, dodged puddles along Gagarin Street, turned the corner at the Gagarin School and finally reached the Gagarin statue in Gagarin Square, where they saw the Soviet astronaut's brother and fellow astronauts celebrate the local boy who on April 12, 1961, became the first human to fly in space. Gagarin, who died in a plane crash in 1968, was a 27-year-old major in the Soviet Air Force when he made his historic flight, orbiting the earth in 108 minutes in a rocket-propelled, five-ton space capsule at a height of 187 miles. He returned to earth as an international hero and was subsequently promoted to colonel.

headline.main: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST

results.snippet: COLORED LIGHT On a sunny day, the brilliance of stained-glass windows by two modern masters, Henri Matisse and Marc Chagall, fills the little sanctuary of the Union Church of Pocantico Hills, N.Y., with abstract light and pure colors.   The windows...
results.lead_paragraph: COLORED LIGHT On a sunny day, the brilliance of stained-glass windows by two modern masters, Henri Matisse and Marc Chagall, fills the little sanctuary of the Union Church of Pocantico Hills, N.Y., with abstract light and pure colors. The windows were commissioned as memorials by members of the Rockefeller family, whose estate is nearby. They represent the final work of Matisse, completed just two days before his death in November 1954, at the age of 84, and the only cycle of church windows done in the United States by Chagall, who died in March 1985 at the age of 97.

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS' FAMILIES EXPECT TO GET REMAINS NEXT MONTH

results.snippet: The space agency has privately told the families of some members of the Challenger crew that their bodies will probably not be released for burial until next month.   Gay Smith, sister-in-law of the shuttle's pilot, Comdr. Michael J. Smith, said...

byline.original: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The space agency has privately told the families of some members of the Challenger crew that their bodies will probably not be released for burial until next month. Gay Smith, sister-in-law of the shuttle's pilot, Comdr. Michael J. Smith, said officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration had told their family that the first weekend in May would be the earliest time funeral services could be held for Commander Smith. ''But it might be the weekend after that, or even later,'' she said, referring to the family plans for a ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery.

headline.main: SPACE PANEL DOUBTS IT CAN PINPOINT DISASTER CAUSE

results.snippet: Members of the Presidential commission investigating the space shuttle disaster said today that they do not expect to be able to identify the precise cause of the explosion that destroyed the Challenger on Jan. 28.   In the commission's first...

byline.original: By PHILIP M. BOFFEY, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Members of the Presidential commission investigating the space shuttle disaster said today that they do not expect to be able to identify the precise cause of the explosion that destroyed the Challenger on Jan. 28. In the commission's first formal news conference, four members of the group's accident analysis panel said that a burned-out section of the shuttle's right booster rocket recovered from the Atlantic Ocean this week provides important confirming evidence that a failure of the rocket joint set off the disaster. But they added that they did not expect that evidence, or any other evidence likely to emerge in the rest of the investigation, to prove what caused the joint to fail. ''I don't believe that we'll home in on any one specific action that caused this failure,'' said Maj. Gen. Donald J. Kutyna of the Air Force, chairman of the analysis panel.

headline.main: ASTRONAUT RETURNS

results.snippet: The Westchester astronaut Jeffrey A. Hoffman will make a special guest appearance this afternoon at the Hudson River Museum's grand farewell to Halley's comet.   A native of Scarsdale, where his parents, Dr. Burton Hoffman and his wife, Betty,...
results.lead_paragraph: The Westchester astronaut Jeffrey A. Hoffman will make a special guest appearance this afternoon at the Hudson River Museum's grand farewell to Halley's comet. A native of Scarsdale, where his parents, Dr. Burton Hoffman and his wife, Betty, still live, the younger Dr. Hoffman is taking a break from his training at the Johnson Space Center in Houston to return to the county for the festivities. Dr. Hoffman flew aboard his first space shuttle mission last April, and he was scheduled for a second launch last month - a mission designed for the study of Halley's comet and cancelled after the space-shuttle disaster.

headline.main: A 'Living' Memorial To Honor an Astronaut

results.snippet: Dr. Marvin Resnik's weekend began and ended at home in Akron, Ohio. But on Saturday night, he attended a reception on East End Avenue to help raise money for a memorial honoring his daughter, the astronaut Judith A. Resnik.

byline.original: By Susan Heller Anderson and David W. Dunlap

results.lead_paragraph: Dr. Marvin Resnik's weekend began and ended at home in Akron, Ohio. But on Saturday night, he attended a reception on East End Avenue to help raise money for a memorial honoring his daughter, the astronaut Judith A. Resnik.

headline.main: RISKS WERE SPELLED OUT, SHUTTLE 'SURVIVOR' SAYS

results.snippet: Christa McAuliffe climbed aboard the space shuttle Challenger well informed of the risk she was taking as the first private citizen to participate in a space mission, according to Barbara R. Morgan, her backup for the flight.   From the moment the...
results.lead_paragraph: Christa McAuliffe climbed aboard the space shuttle Challenger well informed of the risk she was taking as the first private citizen to participate in a space mission, according to Barbara R. Morgan, her backup for the flight. From the moment the two schoolteachers began the five-month training, Mrs. Morgan said, they were reminded many times, in many ways, of the hazards of space flight, particularly launching and landing. They trained with the six other crew members in making emergency escapes from the launching pad or from the shuttle after a hazardous landing. They learned how to put out fires in the crew compartment and to protect themselves against noxious fumes.

headline.main: SENATORS UNEASY ON NASA BUT OPTIMISTIC ON NOMINEE

results.snippet: Key Senators said today that they were disturbed at reports of waste and mismanagement in the space agency when it was headed by James C. Fletcher, but they indicated they would still vote to confirm him as the next head of the agency.   Dr....

byline.original: By PHILIP M. BOFFEY, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Key Senators said today that they were disturbed at reports of waste and mismanagement in the space agency when it was headed by James C. Fletcher, but they indicated they would still vote to confirm him as the next head of the agency. Dr. Fletcher faced some penetrating questions when he appeared before the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation for a confirmation hearing this afternoon, but most Republicans and Democrats generally supported his nomination. Dr. Fletcher, who headed the National Aeronautics and Space Administration from 1971 to 1977, was asked by President Reagan in March to return to the agency to fill a leadership vacuum. The agency has been without a permanent head since James M. Beggs, the Administrator, took a leave of absence in December to fight an indictment on Federal fraud charges unconnected with his work at NASA. He later resigned.

headline.main: Remains of Challenger Crew Will Be Flown to Dover, Del.

results.snippet: The remains of the seven crew members of the space shuttle Challenger are to be flown to Dover Air Force Base in Delaware on Tuesday for final treatment in accordance with the families' wishes, the space agency announced today.
results.lead_paragraph: The remains of the seven crew members of the space shuttle Challenger are to be flown to Dover Air Force Base in Delaware on Tuesday for final treatment in accordance with the families' wishes, the space agency announced today.

headline.main: NASA NOMINEE GETS A ONCE-OVER

results.snippet: SENATORS were clearly concerned last week by reports that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration had wasted more than $3.5 billion while cutting or delaying safety expenditures for the space shuttle.   But the senators did not seem...
results.lead_paragraph: SENATORS were clearly concerned last week by reports that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration had wasted more than $3.5 billion while cutting or delaying safety expenditures for the space shuttle. But the senators did not seem disturbed enough to block President Reagan's nomination of James C. Fletcher, who presided over the space agency from 1971 to 1977, when much of the waste occurred, to return to his old job as its Administrator.

headline.main: BODIES OF ASTRONAUTS FLOWN TO DELAWARE

results.snippet: The crew of the space shuttle Challenger lifted off for the last time from the Kennedy Space Center today, in seven metal coffins riding in the cargo bay of an Air Force transport plane.   Escorted by members of the astronaut corps, the remains of...

byline.original: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The crew of the space shuttle Challenger lifted off for the last time from the Kennedy Space Center today, in seven metal coffins riding in the cargo bay of an Air Force transport plane. Escorted by members of the astronaut corps, the remains of the Challenger crew were flown to a military mortuary at Dover Air Force Base in Delaware. From Dover, they are to be turned over to family members who are making funeral arrangements. A moment after it took off, the four-engine jet carrying the remains of the crew banked over the empty gantry of Launching Pad 39-B, from which the Challenger blasted off on its fatal flight three months ago. The shuttle broke apart 73 seconds into its flight, destroying the spaceship and killing its crew.
